paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine induce a type I interferonâ€“rich inflammatory state that sensitizes tumors to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled murine tumor efficacy experiments testing intratumoral mRNA vaccine combined with anti-PD-L1 therapy for tumor control outcomes.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched murine control arms including vaccine-only, checkpoint inhibitor-only, and vehicle groups to benchmark the combination effect.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors, analyzed by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort with documented prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before or around ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subset of the retrospective metastatic cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination, used as the comparator subgroup for outcomes.

major_limitations: Human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems.
